description.plain:
Macklemore is a rapper who is probably best known for his creative musical endeavor with producer Ryan Lewis which spawned the number one hits “Can’t Hold Us” (six million copies sold, multi-platinum) and “Thrift Shop” (ten million copies sold, multi-platinum, viewed more than a billion times on Youtube) in 2012. But there is more to him than a radio hit and a meme song.

Born June 19, 1983 as Ben Haggerty, the Seattle native of Irish descent has been releasing music independently since 2000. Formerly known as “Professor Macklemore”, he bonded with Ryan Lewis in 2008. The rapper-producer-duo gained a significant online fanbase before making their mainstream breakthrough and gaining international recognition.

Their debut studio album The Heist, released 2012, was a major commercial success, charting #2 on the US Billboard 200 charts, selling 78,000 copies in the first week. It also won a Grammy for best rap album, one which was heatedly debated.

The duo’s sophomore album This Unruly Mess I’ve Made couldn’t meet high expectations. In 2016, Macklemore and Ryan Lewis split on friendly terms for the time being. Macklemore has since been performing solo again, and came with an album in 2017, GEMINI. Altogether, Macklemore has released one mixtape, two EPs and four albums without major label support. Most recently, in 2021, Macklemore and Ryan Lewis came back together for the single “Next Year”.

In his lyrics, Macklemore comes through with comedic lines and political topics side by side. He addresses same-sex marriage, injustice and elections. He also openly discusses drug addiction, having a drug-influenced past himself.

Since Macklemore is a family man, his wife Tricia Davis (married 2015), daughters Sloane Ava Simone (born 2015) and Colette Koala (born 2018), and son Hugo Jack (born 2021) also deserve mention.

songs.title: Glorious

description.plain:
Macklemore feels glorious on his appropriately titled, platinum-certified single featuring Skylar Grey, released June 15, 2017.

Full of renewed confidence, Macklemore expresses a great desire to create new music. Skylar on the choruses acts as his inner voice, emphasizing his passion for music and reinforcing the feeling that he was born to make music.

The single had the nature of a comeback song, being Macklemore’s first release after half a year and 2016’s “Wednesday Morning”, his first solo music after parting ways with producer Ryan Lewis, and the first single from a new album.

Macklemore’s daughter Sloane teased the song ahead of its release before Macklemore revealed title and feature one day later. The song’s music video stars Macklemore’s 100-year-old grandma Helen.

songs.title: Otherside

description.plain:
Macklemore’s “Otherside” deals with drug use in the rap game, specifically using Pimp C as an example, who died after overdosing on cough syrup in 2007. As well as being about the plagues of drug use, the song in a greater sense is about the dangers of idol worship, particularly when that idol is someone like Lil Wayne, who advertises—even glorifies—drugs like lean in his lyrics.

The backtrack is taken from the Red Hot Chilli Pepper’s track “Otherside.” Speaking on the song’s background, Macklemore said:

It started out with just a loop of the music, Red Hot Chili Peppers, and I didn’t really know where I wanted to take the song, I didn’t have a preconceived notion, like, this is gonna be a song about drugs, this is gonna be a song about my experience, it just kind of came. And it was one of those moments in songwriting when the song just writes itself. I just started to kind of writing a narrative of an experience.

As the song unfolds, it becomes clear that Macklemore also discusses his own personal history with drug abuse and how he has seen friends lose the battle with addiction. He explained:

I’ve had a lot of friends that have struggled with drugs and alcohol, struggled with drug addiction, along with myself. And part of the story is kind of a narrative, a glimpse into somebody else’s life, and part of it is my own experience. So by the time that you’re getting into the second verse, I’m talking about my own struggles, my own ups and downs with drugs and alcohol that inevitably left me at a rock bottom and a place where I needed to get sober.

The song seems like a good look at the “otherside” of many rappers that the press and fans don’t necessarily get to see.

The song was remixed by Ryan Lewis and was featured on their 2010 joint project The VS. Redux. The remix features Seattle artist Fences.

songs.full_title: Good Old Days by Macklemore (Ft. Kesha)
songs.title: Good Old Days

description.plain:
“Good Old Days” is about making the most of life so years later you aren’t dwelling on past experiences with regret., possibly with regret.  Ben looks back on his own experiences that might not have been appreciated as much at the time, but were truly good times, and now they’re behind him.

Value in your experiences as you’re experiencing them, living them to the fullest, so years later you aren’t dwelling on them, wishing you acted differently, made different choices, or took advantage of the situation in a better way.

Live life in the moment, live without regret, so when you look back on the good times there won’t be room to improve them.

Macklemore reflects on his days performing in relative anonymity at small venues, just hoping to get his name written down somewhere. He reflects on his time as a high school student when he just wished he asked a girl out.

songs.full_title: Drug Dealer by Macklemore (Ft. Ariana DeBoo)
songs.title: Drug Dealer

description.plain:
While Macklemore & Ryan Lewis have made songs about addiction in the past; check “Kevin” from This Unruly Mess I’ve Made, this track is from Macklemore’s MTV documentary Prescription for Change: Ending America’s Opioid Crisis, which features a discussion between Macklemore and President Barack Obama. The hour-long documentary aired on MTV on the 11th of October 2016.

The track takes aim at the pharmaceutical industry in America, whom Macklemore has claimed is partly to blame for his own addiction to prescription drugs.

songs.title: Marmalade

description.plain:
Not about having breakfast, but about cruising: “Marmalade” finds Macklemore alone on the road, riding through his hometown Seattle and bumping music loudly.

But why is it called “Marmalade”?!

Characteristic for the song, which features a third verse from Lil Yachty, are the high and clear piano keys played by producer Budo. Some have noted the suspicious resemblance to DRAM’s “Broccoli” (which also features Lil Yachty).

Recorded during election night 2016, the song premiered on July 26, 2017 on Beats 1 Radio. Following “Glorious”, it was the second single from Macklemore’s studio album GEMINI. In the song’s music video, kids take the leading role and play young Macklemore and young Lil Yachty cruising through town in a black Maybach.

This is not the first time we feel like sitting in Macklemore’s passenger seat—the song has some similarity with “White Walls” and “Downtown”. Clearly, Macklemore loves to share his experience on the road in his music.

songs.title: White Privilege

description.plain:
Macklemore’s a white rapper, in dialog with his fans and himself on this track. He acknowledges that he may be “gentrifying” hip-hop as a white rapper in a black art form, similar to Eminem in “White America”. Macklemore doesn’t necessarily come to a resolution in this song—rap is who he is, but his privilege is a factor is his success. Also, future Thrift Shop collaborator Wanz said that this was the song that helped him gain respect for Mack:

He was the first rapper that I’d ever heard that would be so bold and so honest as to say a line, “We’ve taken their 40 acres, now I’m taking their 16 bars.” And that’s the line that hooked me, that got me to everything else, like “Other Side” and “Wings” and everything.

In 2007, Macklemore talked about this song, saying:

Me being white and being in a culture that started predominately with people of color, I feel like it’s my responsibility to address the issue, take it upon myself to do it in a fashion that examines it front and back.

When Macklemore got a mainstream following, he maintained this perspective which he discusses in an interview, years after this song was released.

On January 22nd 2016, a follow-up to this song, called “White Privilege II”, was released on YouTube and SoundCloud. The track will be a part of This Unruly Mess I’ve Made – Macklemore & Ryan Lewis' second studio album. The song analyzes a variety of issues centered around race that Macklemore feels are affecting the world still in 2016.

songs.title: Willy Wonka

description.plain:
Flavorful flow and delicious “bars” – the fourth track on GEMINI is dedicated to fictional character Willy Wonka and his chocolate factory.

This song features Offset from Migos and consists of one verse from each rapper. They draw parallels between themselves and Willy Wonka, hence the title of the song—especially the concept—and the repetition in the chorus.

The appearance from the Migos member and the Gemini himself provides us with one of the hype-songs from the album.

description.plain:
This song is a satirical look at American culture from the viewpoint of a “redneck” named Aberdeen Washington, who is likely from Texas.

Macklemore makes him out to sound uneducated and generally narrow minded in a powerful criticism of Southern ideals.

songs.title: Wednesday Morning

description.plain:
The title “Wednesday Morning” references the day proceeding one of the most stressing and polarizing elections in decades. Macklemore delves on the plethora of stances and opinions following Donald Trump’s unexpected win in the presidential election. While many people woke up the following morning—a Wednesday—upset and unable to deal with the results, there were many who were excited with those results.

Macklemore takes his time to voice his opinion on the election result and how citizens need to keep going and deal with the issues that face them together and to the best of their abilities.  He talks about the issues surrounding the President-elect and stating how Trump’s ideas can be stopped and that everyone needs to detoxify and release all the hatred and prejudice, and how everyone should come together.

songs.title: Intentions

description.plain:
“Intentions” finds Macklemore weighing his ideals against his desires. He intends to better himself through living a more positive lifestyle but is met with the challenging task of actually fulfilling these resolutions. This makes a song full of contradictions.

Dan Caplen’s chorus illustrates the way many people chose to escape from problems—through drugs and alcohol. He is speaking from Macklemore’s point of view, affirming that one day he will change, but even until that day, he will still be comfortable with himself.

It should be noted that Macklemore had issues with using alcohol and drugs as an escape.

On the eleventh track of Gemini, Macklemore and Donna Missal discuss an on-and-off relationship.

While the female part, embodied by Missal, ended the relationship and seems to have moved on, Macklemore has not: He is not “over it”.

songs.full_title: Ain't Gonna Die Tonight by Macklemore (Ft. Eric Nally)
songs.title: Ain’t Gonna Die Tonight
songs.title_with_featured: Ain't Gonna Die Tonight (Ft. Eric Nally)

description.plain:
The opener of GEMINI sounds as if it was made to be the kick-off at many Macklemore shows — indeed, it is the first song performed at each GEMINI Tour show. Macklemore enters the stage to this, ready to perform and about to shut down the stage. The song is an anthem of self-confidence and self-motivation and shows Macklemore aware of his own potential, telling himself that, whatever is going to happen, he is not going to die.

The track was first heard in the official album teaser. Eric Nally contributes the same vigorous and strident chorus vocals that he already contributed to “Downtown”. It makes a triumphant opening song not only at live shows, but also on the album — Macklemore is heating himself up, getting ready to show everyone what he is able to accomplish.

songs.full_title: How To Play the Flute by Macklemore (Ft. King Draino)
songs.title: How To Play the Flute
songs.title_with_featured: How To Play the Flute (Ft. King Draino)

description.plain:
Whoever expected an actual instruction on how to play a flute will be disappointed. The track’s title is, how could it be otherwise, an euphemism for oral sex.

However, the track is backed by a distinctive flute melody, combined with 808 kicks and bass lines. A comedic post-chorus makes this one of the most fun, if not the most fun record on Gemini.

songs.title: Fallin’

description.plain:
Fallin' taken from The Unplanned Mixtape – 2009

Macklemore finds himself going through a tough break-up which leads to him suffering from depression, and not for the first time. He turns to using drugs, alcohol and self-harm as ways to forget about everything and ‘numb’ his pain. He loses his direction and begins to question whether he should just end it all.
